coredata.dc:title: The electron—electron cusp condition for the spherical average of the intracule matrix
coredata.dc:creator: Thakkar, Ajit J.
Smith, Vedene H.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The Kato electron—electron cusp condition is used to derive a corresponding cusp condition for the spherical average of the intracule matrix. The numerical utility of this condition is illustrated by considering the Hart and Herzberg 20-parameter Hylleraas-type wavefunctions for the helium-like ions. It is shown that these functions do not satisty the cusp condition. The analytic utility of the latter is illustrated by considering the asymptotic behaviour of the total X-ray scattering intensity.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 42, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 September 1976 THE ELECTRON-ELECTRON CUSP CONDITION FOR THE SPHERICAL AVERAGE OF THE INTRACULE MATRIX? Ajit J. THAKKAR^ and Vedene H. SMITH Jr. Department of Chemistry, Queen's University, Kingston, Ontario K7L 3N6, Canada Received 25 March 1976 Revised manuscript received 2 June 1976 The Kato electron—electron cusp condition is used to derive a corresponding cusp condition for the spherical average of the intracule matrix. The numerical utility of this condition is illustrated by considering the Hart and Herzberg 20-param- eter Hylleraas-type wavefunctions for the heuum4ike ions. It is shown that these functions do not satisfy the cusp condi- tion. The analytic utility of the latter is illustrated by considering the asymptotic behaviour of the total X-ray scattering intensity. 1. Introduction In a seminal paper [1], Kato showed that the exact eigenfunctions of a non-relativistic hamiltonian for an atom with an infinite-mass nucleus satisfy certain cusp conditions at those points in configuration-space where two particles coalesce. Since then cusp conditions have attracted considerable interest [2—7]. They provide insight into the many-body problem, serve as sensitive tests of an approximate wavefunction, and proffer valuable help in the construction of variational approximations. We show in this paper that the Kato electron—electron cusp condition implies a corresponding condition on the spherical average of the intracule matrix. This condition is of considerable interest since the above spherical average is closely related to the electron—electron pair distribution function [8—10]. As an illustration of the numerical utility of this condition, we consider the 20-parameter Hylleraas-type wavefunctions of Hart and Herzberg for the helium-like ions. It is shov/n that none of these functions satisfy the electron—electron cusp con- dition. As an illustration of the analytic utility of the cusp condition derived here, we discuss the asymptotic be- haviour of the total X-ray scattering intensity. 2. The cusp condition Throughout this paper we shall use atomic units defined by fi = Wg = e = 1. To establish notation and terminology we recall a few definitions. The spin-traced p-particle reduced density matrix for an ^V-electron system [11,12] is defined by !tP\r^r^...,^p;r\,r^...,^'p) V?)./^0''2'' -' p\p + 1T -.-^^C1^ ...,p,p+ I, ...,N)ds^ ...ds^dIp+idFp+2 -d^v. 0) *This research has been supported in part by the National Research Council of Canada. As defined above F^ satisfies the Lowdin normalization convention [II] !r{P\r^,r^...,rp,r^,r^...,rp)dV^V^...&Vp^(y^. (2) The intracule matrix [13] is obtained from F^ as follows. Further details of the derivation are given elsewhere [18]. We have included a factor of 1/2 on both sides ofeq. (12) to emphasize the analogy with the electron-nuclear cusp condition [2] for the spherical average of a diagonal element of F' / lim ^p(r)lp(r)]=-Z. (12) is applicable to molecular systems, although we stated our results for atomic systems. 3. Cusp condition checks for some wavefunctions As an illustration of the numerical utility ofeq. (12) we test the 20-parameter Hart and Herzberg [19] Hylleraas-type wavefunctions for the ground states of the helium-like ions. To show to what extent these wave- functions satisfy eq. (12), and for the sake of completeness eq. (13) as well, the following quantities were com- puted C^=Iim [-\p'(r)lp(r)} , C^ = lim [k h'(r^fh(.r^)], r-rO rif^O AC^ = 100 (Z - C^)IZ , AC^ = 100 (0.5 - C^)fO.S . (16) The computation was trivial in view of the fact that Benesch [20] has tabulated algebraic expressions for .Po0"12) and Dn(r) for these wavefunctions. Benesch also considered the electron—nucleus cusp condition. Note that Table 1 Cusp condition checks for the Hart and Herzberg functions Ion ^en Cee ACen ACee H- 0.9906 0.4534 0.94 9.32 He 2.0030 0.4686. -0.15 6.28 1^ 3.0038 0.4675 -0.13 6.50 B3" 5.0056 0.4624 -0.11 7.52 o6" 8.0059 0.4647 -0.07 7.06 Ne8" 10.0062 0.4646 -0.06 7.08 Mg10" 12.0062 0.4657 -0.05 6.86 478 Volume 42, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 September 1976 p(^)=Do(r)f4^rrt . (17) The results are shown in table 1. It is clear that none of the wavefunctions satisfy either of the cusp conditions. The election—nuclear cusp condition is satisfied to a greater extent than the electron—electron cusp condition in all cases. The wavefunction for H~ is markedly poorer than the other functions from the point of view of the cusp conditions. This is not particularly surprising since it is well known that it is more difficult to obtain accurate wave- functions for H~ than for any of the other two-electron ions. 4. Asymptotic behaviour of the total X-ray scattering intensity From the density matrix formulation of X-ray scattering [21 ], the total intensity /^((I)//Q is given by /tWci =^+2/^(2)(rl,l•2;rl,r2)expO^^•rl2)dFldF:, , (18) where (i= (p., a, 0) and the momentum transfer p. is related to the X-ray wavelength X and scattering angle CJ by p. = 47rsin(<A?/2)/X. For a spherically symmetric electron distribution or for an average over random orientations of a non-spherical -/v-electron gas atom, eq. (18) reduces [9] to oo W/Icl=N+2f Wu) [sin (^•12)^12] ^u - 09) 0 With the help of standard techniques [22] the asymptotic expansion 00 Wl^d - A^ 2 Z) (-1)" ^^(O)/^2"-1^ (20) 11=1 has been obtained [15]. (9) to obtain ^a ItWUci -N ^ -167T/2-4 D <5(r,-.)> + 167T Z) (-1)" nh^-^WIn2^2 . (22) t"</ n=1 The above asymptotic result makes precise the notion that the total scattering intensity for large p. is governed by 2,-<;.<S (r,.)>. The latter quantity also plays a role in relativistic and radiative corrections to the energy [23] . Ob- viously the step from (21) to (22) is valid only for an intensity computed from a wavefunction which satisfies the cusp conditions. The exact wavefunction is one such function. It will be shown elsewhere [24] that a wavefunction of finite -1-rank can never satisfy the cusp condition for h(r^). Note that the leading term of eq. (22) has been given previously; first by one of us [15] and then by Kimball [25]. Note also that use of the cusp condition for h(r^) derived by us has simplified the derivation. Finally we illustrate further the parallelism between results for p(r) and for h(r^) by considering the form factor. If the electron distribution is spherically symmetric, or if one averages over random orientations of a non-spheri- cal gas atom, then [9] the form factor is given by 00 F(f£) = f £>o(r) [sin (utr)fpr\ dr . (13), and the first ofeqs. (15) to write F(ui)^ 16TTZI.T4 S<5(r.)>+8ir £ (-1)" npt2"-1^)/^2""1'2 . / 71=2 (24) (25) The leading term of this expansion has been given previously [26] - The above asymptotic result makes precise the notion that the form factor for large p. is governed by <S,-5(r,)>. The latter quantity plays a role in relativistic and radiative corrections to the energy [23] , and is associated, via a sum rule, to the oscillator-strength distribu- tion of the atom [23] ; Note the close parallelism between eqs. (21),(22) and eqs. (24),(25). 5. Discussion The electron—electron cusp condition for A(rn) that we have derived in this paper should prove very useful in analyses of the electron—electron pair distribution function [8—10] ^o^^)- There has been considerable interest [8—10,14,16,20,27—39] in such analyses particularly in connection with the Coulomb hole function. The latter is defined [8] as the difference between the exact and the Hartree—Fock-PoO"^)- There have been sug- gestions [14,16] that a similar definition that employs a weighted pair distribution function might be more use- ful. The cusp condition, eq. (12), lends support to the redefinition of the Coulomb hole function as the difference between the exact and a reference (e.g. Hartree—Fock) intracule function h(r^). It has been suggested recently [40] that the charge density p(r) is a monotonically decreasing function ofr. In a similar vein, we note that the exact h(r^) cannot be monotonic and, in fact, must possess at least one max- imum. This is evident from the facts that for a state with total spin S <N/2,h(r^) is positive at the origin, is everywhere nonnegative, vanishes at infinity, and satisfies the cusp condition given by eq. (12). Note that this is an example where the parallelism between results for p(r) and h(r^) breaks down. The numerical utility of the cusp condition for h(r^) has been illustrated in section 3. It is worth noting that in the past [41] electron—electron cusp condition checks for non-trivial explicitly-correlated wavefunctions have been made by a Fock-expansion technique. Eq. (12) provides an alternative, and perhaps more convenient, route to such tests. The analytic utility ofeq. (12) has been illustrated in section 4. References (1} 7. Kato.Commun. Pure Appl. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The Kato electron—electron cusp condition is used to derive a corresponding cusp condition for the spherical average of the intracule matrix. The numerical utility of this condition is illustrated by considering the Hart and Herzberg 20-parameter Hylleraas-type wavefunctions for the helium-like ions. It is shown that these functions do not satisty the cusp condition. The analytic utility of the latter is illustrated by considering the asymptotic behaviour of the total X-ray scattering intensity.
